questions.question: In the 'High-Value Somatic Architecture' model, what is the primary shift required to move away from the 'Time-for-Money' trap?
options: Transitioning from hourly billing to outcome-based, structured containers
Increasing the hourly rate until the practitioner reaches their income goal
Working more hours per week to increase total revenue
Exclusively offering 15-minute 'laser' sessions
questions.explanation: High-value architecture focuses on the transformation and outcome provided within a structured container (like a 3-month program) rather than trading individual hours for dollars.

questions.question: When scaling impact via group facilitation, what is the 'Collective Nervous System' referring to?
options: The internet connection used for Zoom calls
The average heart rate of all participants combined
The emergent field of co-regulation and shared arousal states within a group
A specific anatomical structure found in social animals
questions.explanation: In group work, the 'Collective Nervous System' is the shared energetic and physiological field where participants co-regulate or influence each other's states of arousal and safety.

questions.question: According to the lesson on Digital Somatic Assets, what is the biggest challenge in translating somatic work to an 'Evergreen' course?
options: The cost of video editing software
Maintaining safety and self-regulation without the practitioner's live presence
Finding a platform that supports large video files
Collecting payments from international students
questions.explanation: The primary challenge is ensuring the curriculum includes enough 'scaffolding' and safety cues so students can self-regulate effectively without a live facilitator's real-time intervention.

questions.question: In Clinical Supervision and Team Leadership, what does the 'Parallel Process' describe?
options: When two clients have the same symptoms at the same time
When a supervisor and supervisee work in the same office
When the dynamics between a client and practitioner are mirrored in the relationship between the practitioner and supervisor
A method of dual-tasking during somatic exercises
questions.explanation: Parallel process occurs when the relational dynamics or 'stuckness' of the client-practitioner relationship are unconsciously replicated in the supervision sessions.

questions.question: When pitching Somatic Consulting to corporate clients, which terminology is statistically more likely to gain 'buy-in' from executives?
options: Inner Child Healing and Shadow Work
Nervous System Resilience and Peak Performance Optimization
Chakra Balancing and Energy Clearing
Trauma Release Exercises
questions.explanation: Corporate environments prioritize ROI and performance. Using language like 'resilience' and 'optimization' aligns somatic work with their existing goals of productivity and leadership health.

questions.question: What is the 'Integration Gap' often experienced after immersive somatic retreats?
options: The time it takes to travel back from a remote location
The difficulty of maintaining deep somatic shifts when returning to a high-stress daily environment
The space between the end of a retreat and the start of the next one
The difference in price between the retreat and 1:1 sessions
questions.explanation: The integration gap occurs when a participant experiences profound regulation or healing in a 'bubble' (the retreat) but lacks the tools or support to sustain those changes in their normal life.

questions.question: Ethical Marketing for somatic practitioners avoids 'Pain-Point Agitation.' What is the preferred alternative taught in Module 35?
options: Ignoring the client's problems entirely
Using countdown timers to force a quick decision
Consent-based marketing that emphasizes agency and nervous system resonance
Promising a 100% cure for all trauma in one session
questions.explanation: Ethical marketing respects the client's autonomy (agency) and allows them to feel into whether the practitioner's 'vibe' or approach resonates with their system without being pressured.

questions.question: As a 'Visionary Leader' in the somatic field, what is the purpose of expanding your own 'Capacity'?
options: To be able to work 80 hours a week without sleeping
To increase the complexity and volume of the 'energetic holding' required for a larger business or team
To memorize more somatic exercises than any other practitioner
To increase the storage capacity of your digital assets
questions.explanation: Scaling a business requires a practitioner to hold a larger 'container' of responsibility, team dynamics, and client energy; this requires a robust and regulated nervous system.

questions.question: Which of these is a key indicator that a somatic practitioner is ready to scale from 1:1 to Group Facilitation?
options: They have a waitlist for 1:1 sessions and are repeating the same foundational concepts frequently
They are feeling burnt out and want to work less
They have reached 1,000 followers on Instagram
They have finished their first year of practice
questions.explanation: Consistent demand (a waitlist) and the realization that foundational teaching can be delivered effectively to many at once are primary indicators for scaling to groups.

questions.question: In the context of Somatic Team Leadership, what is 'Vicarious Resilience'?
options: The fatigue felt when listening to other people's problems
The positive psychological growth experienced by a practitioner through witnessing their clients' or team's healing
A type of exercise done in pairs
The ability to work without any supervision
questions.explanation: Just as practitioners can experience vicarious trauma, they can also experience vicarious resilienceâ€”being inspired and strengthened by the growth and triumph of those they lead or treat.
